s.text: Good spin wins the issue of the day, but great spin goes further.

"We" refers, of course, to the government.
At his news conference, he made clear that allocating money to poverty-stricken parts of the country isn't subsidizing the poor; it's "investing in America's new markets."

The question, as he put it Thursday, is no longer whether to spend more money on programs but whether "to meet our basic responsibilities in education, defense, the environment," and other commitments.
Four months ago, when George W. Bush launched his presidential exploratory committee, he defended tax cuts by arguing that it was "compassionate" of political leaders "to give people more money."
